bioprojects.title: We developed a theoretical framework which explains why the relationship between growth rate (r) and carrying capacity (K) describes a skew parabola, and applied this parabola to the study of of antibiotic resistance. We demonstrate that, to become resistant, microbes need not to increase r at the cost of K (costs of resistance) but, upon abundance of nutrients, the presence of an antibiotic can lead to an increase in r and K creating a `uberbug'.

We developed a theoretical framework which explains why the relationship between growth rate (r) and carrying capacity (K) describes a skew parabola, and applied this parabola to the study of of antibiotic resistance. We demonstrate that, to become resistant, microbes need not to increase r at the cost of K (costs of resistance) but, upon abundance of nutrients, the presence of an antibiotic can lead to an increase in r and K creating a `uberbug'.

bioprojects.title: Complete genome sequence of Escherichia coli K-12 substrain AB1157, the preferred strain for the DNA metabolism studies

assembly_info.assembly_method: Trycycler v. 0.4.1; Flye v. 2.8.3-b1695; Raven v. 1.5.0; Miniasm v. 0.3-r179; Minipolish v. 0.1.2

description.title: Escherichia coli K12 substr. AB1157
description.comment: AB1157 was isolated in the lab of Edward A. Adelberg, and became the reference strain for Paul Howard-Flanders genetic studies of DNA replication, damage, and repair. An early pioneer in DNA studies, Howard-Flanders favored the strain for its lack of prophage induction and consequent genetic stability under elevated levels of genotoxic stress. To date, AB1157 is still frequently employed as an E. coli reference strain by researchers worldwide.
